awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Luther College to acquire an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). ICP-OES is a powerful instrument able to sensitively measure small amounts of elements such as calcium, iron, zinc, copper, and other metals in various types of complex samples. This instrument will be a valuable resource for enhancing research and education at Luther College where faculty extensively engage undergraduate students in their research activities. The ICP-OES will be a central component of several research programs as well as Chemistry and Environmental Studies courses at Luther College. Access to this technology will enable Luther College faculty to more effectively train the next generation of scientists and provide opportunities for students that are not available in a formal class setting. Additionally, the instrument will allow expansion of ongoing water quality research to complement and strengthen community outreach efforts centered around water, which is vital to our local community and state.

The ICP-OES will expand research directions for both new and ongoing projects at Luther College. One application will investigate how organisms, such as the small nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, regulate metal concentrations. This work will increase our understanding of the role of metals in growth, reproduction, and survival of cells and organisms support. Another project will use the ICP-OES to examine connections between trace metals, antibiotic resistant bacteria, and animal waste in aquatic environments, including surface and ground water. Further, the ICP-OES will enhance an ongoing project focused on how bacteria sense and respond to metals and expand the knowledge of how metals impact bacteria in ecosystems and natural environments. Finally, an innovative project focused on developing novel nanocrystals has the potential for a better understanding of the conversion of light to electrical energy for solar technology applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF MRI grant funded the acquisition of an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) to support research and undergraduate education at Luther College, a liberal arts institution in Decorah, IA. An ICP-OES is used for multi-elemental spectroscopic analysis of samples with high analytical precision. Quantitative elemental analysis is valuable for a wide range of applications in the fields of chemistry, biology, and environmental science. The acquisition of an ICP-OES at Luther College replaced outdated instrumentation that had a limited ability of detecting the presence of a single element at the parts-per-thousand level with the ability for fast, reliable, multi-element analysis at the parts-per-billion level. Acquisition of an ICP-OES has enabled progress of both faculty research and undergraduate instruction in elemental analysis, which was previously not readily accessible due to our rural location without a nearby university with these capabilities. The ICP-OES has enhanced the college's undergraduate science curriculum through its integration into chemistry and environmental sciences coursework and research conducted by faculty-student research teams.

Faculty members in Chemistry, Biology, and Environmental Studies (Drs. Stephanie Fretham, Molly Wilker, Eric Baack, Jodi Enos-Berlage, and John Hedstrom) had a strong need for this instrument to study trace metals in biological and environmental samples and quantify elements in heterogenous nanomaterials. With support from this grant, the ICP-OES has enabled progress for multiple research projects including 1) Investigation of Metal Homeostasis and Metabolic Signaling in Caenorhabditis elegans, a research program using ICP-OES to quantify metabolically relevant trace metals in the nematode; 2) Investigating connections between trace metals and antibiotic resistance, a research program in which ICP-OES assesses trace metals in surface and ground water in northeast Iowa; 3) Characterization of novel nanocrystals for energy conversion, a research program which uses ICP-OES to quantify the components of mixed-metal nanocrystals with a variety of morphologies. 

The overall NSF MRI grant project provided opportunities for research, teaching, and mentoring in science areas. Specifically, research involving elemental analysis with the ICP-OES was made possible for several faculty members and undergraduate students within the Departments of Biology, Chemistry and Environmental Studies. To date, nearly 50 undergraduate students directly benefited from learning to use this instrument including 8 research students that have worked on projects where a significant portion of the work involved using the ICP-OES to collect data for key results. Dr. Wilker along with undergraduate research students have developed a teaching lab experiment highlighting the capabilities of ICP-OES for analysis of trace metals in environmental water samples for use in an advanced chemistry course. The undergraduate students who work on the instrument learn valuable skills in sample preparation, analysis, and data analysis.This hands-on scientific training related to research and instrumentation provides students with valuable experience for direct employment following graduation.
